author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: This Was a Terrible Year, and Also Maybe the Best One Yet for Humanity
description: Child mortality and extreme poverty appear to have reached record lows in the history of civilization.
content: As the year ends, civilians are dying at a staggering pace in Gaza and the genocide in Darfur may be resuming. A man charged with 91 felonies is leading in American presidential polls, and our carbon emissions risk cooking our planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Hannah Beier
title: In a City Defined by History, Chinatown’s Champions Fear New Arena for 76ers
description: Chinatowns in the United States and Canada have long been squeezed by development projects. Will a proposed arena in Philadelphia’s struggling downtown be the next?
content: Deborah Wei first wore a “No Stadium in Chinatown” T-shirt emblazoned with red English letters and Chinese characters in 2000, when she helped to scuttle a proposed baseball stadium for the Phillies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Marpillero-Colomina
title: Electrify All the Big, Noisy, Belching Trucks
description: President Biden seems nervous about sealing a deal that would improve the health and quality of life of millions of Americans through a stricter rule on truck emissions.
content: This morning in Mott Haven, a neighborhood in the South Bronx, tens of thousands of New Yorkers — more than 95 percent of whom are people of color — woke up and breathed in air thick with vehicle exhaust. Hundreds of trucks drive through here daily, to and from the enormous food distribution center Hunts Point Produce Market, as well as other nearby warehouses, shipping facilities and waste transfer stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Ka-Man Tse
title: I Want a City, Not a Museum
description: New York’s layers of laws to protect existing buildings has led to a shortage of housing.
content: Some years ago, as my mother and I were walking on New York City’s Upper West Side, she pointed out a redbrick townhouse in the West 70s where, she said, my great-grandfather had lived as a child. It was an awkward building, the door set back under a large arch, the roof sharply peaked, and I wondered that it had survived as the city rose around it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Surman and Edward Wong
title: Biden Administration Again Bypasses Congress for Weapons Sale to Israel
description: The move comes as Israel presses on with its offensive in Gaza despite increasing pressure from the United States to lower the conflict’s intensity.
content: The Biden administration is bypassing Congress for the second time since the start of the war in Gaza for a weapons sale to Israel, a move that comes amid growing anger at the United States over its backing of Israel as the Gaza death toll rises and misery spreads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mbongeni Ngema, Playwright Best Known for ‘Sarafina!,’ Dies at 68
description: Before the fall of apartheid, his plays, which also included “Woza Albert!” and “Asinamali,” challenged the South African government’s racial policies.
content: Mbongeni Ngema, a South African playwright, lyricist and director whose stage works, including the Tony-nominated musical “Sarafina!,” challenged and mocked his homeland’s longtime policy of racial apartheid, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Mbizana, South Africa, after a car accident. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: A ‘Holopoem’ for the Cosmos
description: Eduardo Kac found an unusual public space for his artwork — orbiting the sun. Celebrated fellow travelers on the rocket: the creator of “Star Trek” and some of the show’s cast.
content: The artist Eduardo Kac was at his New York gallery the other day to show a reporter his work: a hologram encoded on a sliver of glass resting inside a tiny metal case. This little package is the capstone of Kac’s career to date — an artifact he created in 1986 that is now, finally, about to find its intended home in space. On Jan. 8 it is scheduled to be on board a Vulcan Centaur rocket as it lifts off from Cape Canaveral and heads into orbit around the sun. This holographic artwork — a “holopoem,” Kac calls it — might or might not be discovered hundreds of thousands of years from now by whatever creatures are around to find it. But for the moment it was here at the Henrique Faria gallery just off Madison Avenue, about to be viewed by a human.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Zhang
title: 11 Charts That Explain the Year in Business, Technology and the Economy
description: Inflation, bank failures, strikes, and artificial intelligence provided some of the biggest stories and trends of 2023.
content: It has been a confusing year for the economy and markets. At the start of 2023, economists largely predicted a global recession, and Wall Street was bearish on stocks, with many analysts expecting the S&P 500 to finish the year just a touch higher than where it started. Fast-forward 12 months: No recession (yet) and the S&P 500 is tantalizingly close to a record high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: How a Super Affordable Bakery Chain Became a British Culinary Icon
description: A festive pop-up restaurant is the latest crowd-pleasing stunt from Greggs, a mass-market bakery that is riding out Britain’s cost-of-living crisis with gusto.
content: To most of this bakery’s millions of devotees, the idea that its “Steak Bake” could be “lifted” lies somewhere between folly and heresy. It brings diced beef, gravy and crisp puff pastry together in perfect harmony. It cannot be improved, or ameliorated, or heightened. It has already attained its highest form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Boom in A.I. Prompts a Test of Copyright Law
description: The use of content from news and information providers to train artificial intelligence systems may force a reassessment of where to draw legal lines.
content: The boom in artificial intelligence tools that draw on troves of content from across the internet has begun to test the bounds of copyright law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Mutiny Erupts in a Michigan G.O.P. Overtaken by Chaos
description: Republicans are pushing for the removal of Kristina Karamo, an election-denying activist who rose to lead the state party this year, amid mounting financial problems and persistent infighting.
content: The mutiny took hold on Mackinac Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Neighbor Is Feeding Stray Cats, and My Yard Is Their Bathroom
description: Besides creating a nuisance to people, cats who roam freely can damage populations of birds and other wildlife.
content: Q: We live on the first and second floors of a brownstone in East Harlem, and we love the backyard. Two buildings over, a neighbor in the second-floor apartment has put a litter box on the fire escape outside their window for community cats to shelter. The neighbor also puts out food for them. In the morning, there are usually half a dozen adult cats lingering around the box and the stairs. Inevitably, they end up roaming in our backyard, peeing, pooping and fighting. The odor in the summer is terrible. We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone. The kittens are cute, their cries not so much. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Mightier — and Meaner — Than the Sword
description: Emily Cockayne’s “Penning Poison,” a history of anonymous letters, reveals the ways we’ve been torturing one another, verbally, for centuries.
content: Long ago, in a moment of youthful discontent, I stumbled upon a primitive listicle on a now forgotten website that advised the reader on how to deal with feelings of dislike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: New Spin on a Revolving Door: Pentagon Officials Turned Venture Capitalists
description: Retired officers and departing defense officials are flocking to investment firms that are pushing the government to provide more money to defense-technology startups.
content: When Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III and other top officials assembled for an event this month at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, they walked into a lesson in how the high-stakes world of Pentagon lobbying is being altered by the rise of defense technology startups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Willie Ruff, Jazz Missionary and Professor, Dies at 92
description: A master of the French horn, a rarity in jazz, he toured the world with the pianist Dwike Mitchell and taught music at Yale.
content: Willie Ruff, who fashioned an unlikely career in jazz as a French horn player and toured the world as a musical missionary in the acclaimed Mitchell-Ruff Duo while maintaining a parallel career at the Yale School of Music, died on Sunday at his home in Killen, Ala. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Jes Aznar
title: ‘There’s No Other Job’: The Colonial Roots of Philippine Poverty
description: Decades after independence, the Philippines lacks the kind of factory economy that has lifted up other Asian nations, tying millions to farm work.
content: Rodino Sawan stepped into the wire harness and dug his toes into the muddy track that threads the sweltering plantation. He pushed forward, straining against the cargo trailing behind him: 25 bunches of freshly harvested bananas strung from hooks attached to an assembly line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Beth Keane
title: A Body, a Family and the Woman Who Changed Everything
description: In “Mercury,” Amy Jo Burns explores the conflicting loyalties and many secrets of a roofing clan in small-town Pennsylvania.
content: We meet the main players of Amy Jo Burns’s poignant new novel, “Mercury,” in that golden moment between childhood and adulthood, when they’re young and strong, and it’s just dawning on them that their worlds were circumscribed at birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Nursing Student Dreams of Her Own Clinic in Haiti
description: Assistance with school supplies and other essentials helped set a student up for college.
content: Naomie Ambroise, a 19-year-old nursing student, knows exactly where she’ll travel once she has her degree: Japan and Thailand are at the top of her list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Conflict in Israel and Gaza, in Photos
description: A surprise attack by Hamas put Israel and the group that controlled Gaza at war. Here are images from the assault and what has followed.
content: More than two months after a Hamas-led attack in Israel killed 1,200 people, according to officials, the Israeli military is hunting for members of Hamas, the group that runs Gaza, including its most wanted man in the territory: Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader it considers the mastermind of the Oct. 7 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How a Traffic Safety Guru Spends His Sundays
description: Peter Goldwasser, the executive director of Together for Safer Roads, spends his weekends running around Brooklyn — literally.
content: Peter Goldwasser is the executive director of Together for Safer Roads, a nongovernmental organization that works with businesses and city agencies to improve trucking safety and prevent crashes. The group’s ultimate goal is to eliminate traffic fatalities and severe injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debbie Dingell
title: Debbie Dingell: How to Stand Up to Trump
description: The only way to deal with a bully is to consistently call out their inexcusable behavior and defend those they target.
content: “Rot in hell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: 20 Acts in 60 Minutes
description: Instead of the usual three or four stories on a theme, this episode of “This American Life” brings you 20 stories — yes, 20 — in 60 minutes.
content: Instead of the usual “each week we choose a theme, and bring you three or four stories on that theme” business, this episode of “This American Life” throws all that away and brings you 20 stories — yes, 20 — in 60 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump’s Team Prepares to File Challenges on Ballot Decisions Soon
description: The cases in Colorado, Maine and other states are requiring former President Donald J. Trump to devote resources already spread thin across four criminal indictments.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s advisers are preparing as soon as Tuesday to file challenges to decisions in Colorado and Maine to disqualify Mr. Trump from the Republican primary ballot because of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, according to a person familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Toast to a Year and a Word
description: As we raise a glass to the past year and the one ahead, let’s explore the history of the tradition and its name.
content: Toasting is a tradition that dates back to ancient Greece. The act of raising a glass to wish someone good fortune “came around even before the word,” Paul Dickson, the author of a book on toasts, told Times Insider. For example, Ulysses drank to Achilles’ health in Homer’s “Odyssey,” though the word itself was not used in the poem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Tom Wilkinson, Actor in ‘The Full Monty,’ Dies at 75
description: A versatile actor who also starred in “Shakespeare in Love” and “Batman Begins,” he won acclaim through decades of work in television and film and onstage.
content: Tom Wilkinson, the actor who could turn a manic lawyer, a steel-foreman-turned-stripper and parts small and large into mesmerizing turns, winning Oscar nominations and plaudits for his performances in movies like “Michael Clayton” and “The Full Monty,” died on Saturday, according to a family statement. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Twists Can Thicken It
description: Simeon Seigel breaks some rules in the final Saturday puzzle of 2023.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — What did Simeon Seigel do to us here in his debut Saturday construction? Maybe it’s no coincidence that he has mainly specialized in Thursday grids. This puzzle includes eight unchecked squares, typically a crossword no-no. Each of them sports a circle, which indicates some sort of theme, which is typically a Saturday no-no. Oh, and every black square in the entire grid is disconnected from every other black square, even on the diagonal, which is typically, well … considered impossible? Rarer than rare, perhaps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: As War Rages in Ukraine, Denmark Turns an Office Park Back Into an Arsenal
description: The conflict and surging arms production in Russia have spurred demand for ammunition manufacturing across Europe.
content: The old Krudten ammunition plant, near the northernmost tip of Denmark, is a quiet shell of a factory that has sat empty for years despite its legacy of churning out bullets, artillery and explosives for the Danish military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: An Israeli hostage describes her time in captivity in harrowing detail.
description: An account of being held for 55 days in Gaza has touched a particular nerve in Israel.
content: Mia Schem had been held hostage in Gaza for three days when, she said, she underwent surgery for a gunshot wound she sustained in Hamas’s attack on Israel. For days afterward — forced to share a room with her captor — she received no painkillers and had to replace her own bandages.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the Humanities Are Indeed Worth Teaching
description: Readers respond to a guest essay by a philosophy professor about difficulties defending the humanities.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about the Ukrainian Orthodox Church’s decision to move Christmas to Dec. 25 referred incorrectly to the Eastern Orthodox Church in Finland. The church there does not use the Julian calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Anna Betts, Mike Baker and Jill Cowan
title: Would Keeping Trump Off the Ballot Hurt or Help Democracy?
description: Some critics say the battles over the former president’s ballot status are turning him into a martyr and eroding faith in American elections.
content: As the top elections official in Washington State, Steve Hobbs says he is troubled by the threat former President Donald J. Trump poses to democracy and fears the prospect of his return to power. But he also worries that recent decisions in Maine and Colorado to bar Mr. Trump from presidential primary ballots there could backfire, further eroding Americans’ fraying faith in U.S. elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Fire Breaks Out Aboard Ship Carrying Lithium-Ion Batteries
description: The vessel, now off the Alaskan coast, is carrying nearly 2,000 tons of lithium-ion batteries, which contain highly flammable materials, officials said.
content: The authorities on Saturday continued to assess how to fight a fire that broke out two days ago aboard a cargo ship that is carrying nearly 2,000 tons of lithium-ion batteries and was ordered to remain off the Alaskan coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: How ‘That Octopus Book’ Won Over More Than a Million Readers
description: With its beguiling octopus narrator, Shelby Van Pelt’s “Remarkably Bright Creatures” has notable staying power and is back on the best-seller list — a year and a half after its release.
content: Last year during the holiday sales rush, Beth Seufer Buss started getting an unusual request from customers at Bookmarks, the independent bookstore where she works in Winston-Salem, N. C.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: America’s Diet Is Feeding a Groundwater Crisis
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 30, 2023.
content: “Our aquifer is slowly depleting every year. It’s going away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Words of Wisdom
description: Readers share the best advice they received this year.
content: There’s such fanfare about the end of the year and the beginning of a new one, but the difference is only a day. I find myself thinking about this a lot, how we invest the turning-over of a new year with such meaning, but it’s really just a Sunday into Monday, a transition we don’t dignify with ceremony the other 51 weeks. This week, it’s momentous. This week, we make a fuss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s Raucous Holiday Classics Are Not Your Standard Hallmark Movies
description: Gleefully vulgar, the genre known as “Cinepanettone” once dominated Italy over the holidays. Italian revelers recently flocked to the alpine town where many of the films were set.
content: On a recent evening inside the Hotel de la Poste, an alpine hotel in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy’s most ski-and-be-seen winter destination, a boisterous party celebrated the birth of a cinematic era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Times Insider Staff and Sarah Mazzetti
title: 72 of Our Favorite Facts of 2023
description: Each day, Times Insider editors scour the newspaper for the most interesting facts to appear in articles. Tidbits about Cookie Monster, the ‘Sodfather’ and leaf blowers surprised, enlightened and entertained us this year.
content: 1. The title character of the film “Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio” is the first metal 3-D-printed puppet. It was animated using some 3,000 replacement faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Shrimp Pasta, Chicken Tagine, Noodle Soup and Mushroom Stroganoff
description: Dinners that meet you where you are as we close out 2023.
content: It’s Saturday morning, and 2024 is two sleeps away. There are two ways to approach this last weekend of the year: party hearty, or quiet cozy. Either plan is excellent, and today’s newsletter is dedicated to meals that are perfectly suited for whichever type of New Year’s weekend you’d like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: A Midwestern Republican Stands Up for Trans Rights
description: Ohio’s governor reminds Republicans that they’re supposed to support parents’ rights, even if their children are trans.
content: As 2023 slouches to an ignominious end, some news came Friday that gave me an unexpected jolt of hope. I have spent much of the year watching with horror and trying to document an unrelenting legal assault on queer and trans people. Around 20 states have passed laws restricting access to gender-affirming care for trans and nonbinary people, and several have barred transgender and nonbinary people from using bathrooms that align with their gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Way Big Banks Shut Down Customer Accounts Is Callous. Let’s Fix It.
description: When banks close checking and credit-card accounts because of “suspicious activity,” chaos and anxiety ensue. It doesn’t have to be this way.
content: For most of the last year, my inbox has been overflowing with tales from people like these:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Tabor
title: Can an Ambitious Public University Still Be a Place for All Students?
description: Stony Brook University, one of two state schools designated as flagships, has aggressively fund-raised and recruited students.
content: Shortly after she became governor of New York, Kathy Hochul made an announcement that caught the higher-education world off guard: The state, which has generally regarded all its public universities as equals, would start treating two universities as “flagships.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Man Survives Six Days Trapped in Pickup Truck Wreckage
description: Fishermen discovered the man after he crashed his pickup, which landed under a bridge in Indiana, hiding him from drivers above, the authorities said.
content: Two men near Portage, Ind., were scouting a creek for potential fishing spots on Tuesday when they spotted a shiny object through the trees. They moved closer and saw that it was a mangled vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It’s Going Down
description: With a zig and a zag, Matt Linzer and Rafael Musa’s collaboration drops us into 2024.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: When a Restaurant Is More Than a Place to Dine
description: We asked Canada Letter readers to tell us about the restaurants that have become institutions in their communities.
content: To end the year, we’re catching up on some old business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Paula Abdul Accuses Nigel Lythgoe of Sexual Assault During ‘American Idol’
description: Ms. Abdul filed a lawsuit against Mr. Lythgoe, a producer of the reality show, that accuses him of assaulting her in an elevator. He called the allegations “false” and “deeply offensive.”
content: Paula Abdul filed a lawsuit on Friday against Nigel Lythgoe, a former longtime producer of “American Idol,” accusing him of sexually assaulting her when she was a judge on the reality show in the early 2000s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah John
title: The Statue of Liberty Hat
description: Paying an unexpected price for a novelty crown.
content: It is early April, in the evening. I’m walking through Times Square on my way to a birthday dinner at a restaurant I’ve never been to. As I weave through the souvenir stands, I’m trying to concentrate on the instructions on my phone screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: The Pentagon Road to Venture Capital
description: Here is a list of people who have jumped from the Pentagon and other government posts into jobs with venture capitalists that are backing defense technology startups.
content: For decades, national security personnel have moved from jobs at the Pentagon to positions at major military contractors. More recently, a growing number of senior Pentagon officials are leaving to take positions at venture capital or private equity firms that invest in a new generation of Silicon Valley-style defense tech startups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Ask Appeals Court to Reject Trump’s Immunity Claims in Election Case
description: The filing by the special counsel, Jack Smith, was the latest move in an ongoing battle over whether former presidents can be criminally liable for things they did while in office.
content: Federal prosecutors asked an appeals court on Saturday to reject former President Donald J. Trump’s claims that he is immune from criminal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election and said the indictment should remain in place even though it arose from actions he took while in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Chick-fil-A’s Closed-on-Sunday Policy Prompts a Highway Rest Stop Revolt
description: New York’s overhaul of its busy Thruway stops includes several Chick-fil-A restaurants. But lawmakers appear to be too late to force a change in the chain’s business hours.
content: Kelli Bogacz had just spent a week camping in the Adirondack Mountains, and as she and her husband negotiated the five-hour drive back home to Buffalo, all they wanted was something to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: How a Russian Barrage Evaded Ukraine’s Defenses to Wreak Deadly Chaos
description: In one of the war’s largest bombardments, 35 missiles slipped through Ukraine’s air cover on Friday, killing dozens. Ukraine responded with shelling on the Russian region of Belgorod, killing at least 14.
content: For months, Ukraine’s use of powerful Western-supplied air-defense systems to repel Russian missile attacks has provided its citizens with some reassurance that a protective shield was effectively in place over big cities such as the capital, Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Ukrainian Missile Attack on a Russian City Kills at Least 20, Officials Say
description: The bombardment of Belgorod on Saturday, apparently in response to an enormous air assault by Moscow a day earlier, appeared to be the deadliest single attack on Russian soil since the start of the war.
content: The Russian authorities said on Saturday that a Ukrainian attack on the city of Belgorod had killed at least 20 people and injured more than 110 others, in what would be the deadliest single assault against a Russian city since the start of the war nearly two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Katz
title: An Artist in Residence on A.I.’s Territory
description: Alexander Reben is taking his tech-savvy perspective to OpenAI, a company that some in the art world believe is a threat to their future.
content: At a reception for OpenAI’s first developer conference in San Francisco last month, a crowd mingled, wine in hand, as withering criticism of art created with artificial intelligence flashed on a blue wall at the front of the room. “I’ve seen more engaging art from a malfunctioning printer,” one critic jabbed. “The fine-art equivalent of elevator music,” huffed another. “Inoffensive, unmemorable and terminally dull.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti, Natan Odenheimer, Alexander Cardia, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Sheera Frenkel
title: Where Was the Israeli Military?
description: A Times investigation found that troops were disorganized, out of position and relied on social media to choose targets. Behind the failure: Israel had no battle plan for a massive Hamas invasion.
content: Far beneath the Israeli military headquarters in Tel Aviv, in a bunker known as The Pit, commanders were trying to make sense of reports of Hamas rocket fire in southern Israel early on the morning of Oct. 7, when the call came in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Dinner for One,’ a German New Year’s TV Tradition, Moves Online
description: The British comedy short has aired annually in Germany and other European countries for decades. Now, members of Gen Z are having fun with it on social media.
content: “OK, the butler’s setting the table,” the YouTuber Ryan Wass begins, skeptically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Workers on a Philippines Coconut Farm: Born Poor, Staying Poor
description: In the groves of the Philippine island of Mindanao, people living in rural areas struggle to feed themselves in the same way as their ancestors.
content: Like most of the those working in the coconut groves that fill out the northern lip of the Philippine island of Mindanao, Diego G. Limbaro has never imagined another life. His father pulled himself up the skinny tree trunks of the surrounding plantations, wielding a machete to detach coconuts. So did his father’s father.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, December 31, 2023
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?
content: Can you sort 8 historical events?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vishaan Chakrabarti
title: How to Make Room for One Million New Yorkers
description: New York needs affordable housing. My architecture studio has a plan for where — and how — the city can build 500,00 new homes.
content: New York needs affordable housing. My architecture studio has a plan for where — and how — the city can build 500,00 new homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Upshot Staff
title: 10 Data Points and Documents That Made Us 🤔 in 2023
description: The Upshot staff shares a selection of their favorite charts, documents, queries and calculations from the past year.
content: The Upshot staff shares a selection of their favorite charts, documents, queries and calculations from the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Kevin Quealy
title: Week 17 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: A Team-by-Team Guide
description: Detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs.
content: Detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times
